start.title:
Building a Synthesizer

Exploring Equal Temperament and the Math of Musical Harmony
start.description: Can you help Emery build a synth that creates harmonious melodies for the school fair? In this STEAMQuest, you’ll explore musical ratios, frequencies and equal temperament to craft a synth that balances perfect intervals and seamless transitions.

S2_D1_F4_C2.heading: Welcome to the Sound Design Lab!
S2_D1_F4_C2.body: I’m Noelle and joining me is Emery, an enthusiastic student ready to dive into the science of sound. Together, we’ll explore the magic of musical ratios, intervals, and how math shapes the way we hear and create music.

S3.S3_D1_F12_C2: Hey Emery, excited for the school fair? I hear you're planning to build a synthesizer for the event!
S3.S3_D2_F13_C1: Yeah! I've always wanted to create and control my own music, but... I have no idea where to start. How do you even make sound with a synth?
S3.S3_D3_F14_C2: Well, it's all about understanding the science behind sound! You see, sound is made up of vibrations, and to create music, we need to manipulate those vibrations.
S3.S3_D4_F15_C1: So, what's the first step in making those vibrations work for music?
S3.S3_D5_F16_C2: Great question! The first thing to understand is that different pitches, or notes, are just vibrations happening at different speeds. The speed of these vibrations is called frequency, and it's measured in hertz (Hz), that's how many vibrations happen per second.
S3.S3_D6_F17_C1: So, faster vibrations mean a higher pitch, and slower vibrations mean a lower pitch, right?
S3.S3_D7_F18_C2: That's correct! When you play two notes together, the ratio between their frequencies determines how they sound when combined. If the ratio is simple, like 2:1, the notes will sound harmonious together.
S3.S3_D8_F19_C1: So, if the frequency of one note is twice as fast as another, they sound good together?
S3.S3_D9_F20_C2: Yes! That's an example of an octave. So, if you play a note and then play it one octave higher, it sounds similar, but with a higher pitch.

S4.S4_D1_F22_C2: There are more important ratios such as the perfect fifth (3:2). It's one of the most harmonious intervals in music.
S4.S4_D2_F23_C1: So, these ratios are the building blocks of melodies and harmonies?
S4.S4_D3_F24_C2: Yes! When the ratio is simple, like 2:1 or 3:2, the notes sound smooth and harmonious. But with more uneven ratios, like 15:8, the sound has more tension — we call that a more complex or dissonant sound.
S4.S4_D4_F25_C1: Wait, so the harmony of music is based on mathematical ratios? That's wild!
S4.S4_D5_F26_C2: Let's hear them out! I've set up a tool so we can listen to the differences between the octaves and perfect fifths.

about.heading: Understanding Music Intervals
about.body:
• Musical Intervals describe how far apart two notes are in terms of pitch. Instead of measuring this distance as a simple difference in frequency, musicians describe it as a ratio between the two frequencies.
  • Octave (2:1 ratio): When one note’s frequency is exactly double another’s, the two notes sound similar but at different pitches. This is called an octave.
  • Perfect Fifth (3:2 ratio): A perfect fifth occurs when the second note’s frequency is 1.5 times the first note’s frequency. This interval sounds harmonious and is used frequently in music.
  • Frequency and Pitch: Pitch is determined by frequency—higher frequencies correspond to higher pitches. Each interval is defined by the proportional relationship between the frequencies of two notes, not by their numeric difference.

help.heading: How to Use Musical Interval Visualization
help.body:
• Click the "Play Sequence" button to hear the notes and the interval between them. First, you will hear the 440 Hz note (A), followed by 880 Hz (A'), and then both together.
  • Do the same for perfect fifth as well. Click the "Play Sequence" button to hear the notes and the interval between them. First, you will hear the 440 Hz note (A), followed by 660 Hz (E), and then both together.

interactive_data.playNoteAPrime: Play note A prime at 880 Hertz
interactive_data.playingBothOctave: Playing both A (440 Hz) and A prime (880 Hz) together - octave interval
interactive_data.playingBothFifth: Playing both A (440 Hz) and E (660 Hz) together - perfect fifth interval
interactive_data.visualizationDescription: This visualization shows three notes on a horizontal line: A at 440 Hz on the left, {0} in the middle, and A prime at 880 Hz on the right. Active notes are highlighted with red markers.
interactive_data.octaveRatioDescription: The ratio of frequencies is 880 divided by 440, which equals 2 to 1, representing an octave.
interactive_data.fifthRatioDescription: The ratio of frequencies is 660 divided by 440, which equals 3 to 2, representing a perfect fifth.

S5.S5_D1_F28_C2: First, we'll check out the octave. We will hear the note 440 Hz, then 880 Hz, which is exactly double the frequency. This is a 2:1 ratio, and we call it an octave.
S5.S5_D2_F29_C2: The notes will sound similar, just one higher than the other. That gap between pitches is called an interval — and this one, with a 2:1 ratio, is one of the most natural. Click ‘Play Sequence’ to hear it!
S5.S5_D3_F30_C1: Wow! They sound really good together — like they fit, even though one’s higher. It feels like the same note, just at a different level.
S5.S5_D4_F31_C2: That's right! It's amazing how these common ratios create such a pleasing sound. Now, let's move on to the perfect fifth!
S5.S5_D5_F32_C1: So, this one's different from the octave?
S5.S5_D6_F33_C2: Yep! In the perfect fifth, the second note's frequency is in a 3:2 ratio with the first note's frequency. Let's listen to 440 Hz and 660 Hz. This 3:2 ratio creates a rich, harmonious sound. Go ahead and click 'Play Sequence' to hear the difference!
S5.S5_D7_F34_C1: Oh, that sounds really nice too! It's not quite as familiar as the octave, but it still feels like they belong together.
S5.S5_D8_F35_C2: You got it! The perfect fifth has a rich, pleasant sound you’ll hear in lots of music, especially in chords. What’s cool is that even when the ratios aren’t as simple, they can still sound harmonious — just in a more layered or textured way.

S6.S6_D1_F36_C1: I'm starting to get how these ratios work. It's like the building blocks of music!
S6.S6_D2_F37_C2: That's right! And speaking of building blocks, we use these ratios to divide the octave into smaller steps—specifically, 12 equal steps, also called semitones.
S6.S6_D3_F38_C1: So, why not more or fewer steps? What makes 12 the magic number?
S6.S6_D4_F39_C2: Because it balances mathematical accuracy and playability. That’s why most modern instruments, like pianos and guitars, use 12 semitones per octave.

about.heading: Exploring Musical Temperament and the Perfect Fifth
about.body:
• Equal Temperament Tuning: Equal temperament is a tuning system where the octave is divided into equal steps. This system, commonly used in instruments like pianos and guitars, makes it possible to play in any key without retuning. The most common version divides the octave into 12 equal steps, each step representing a semitone.
  • Perfect Fifth (3:2 ratio): The perfect fifth interval is considered one of the most harmonious. It is defined by a 3:2 frequency ratio. In equal temperament tuning, this interval is closely approximated, though not mathematically exact.

help.heading: How to Use the Musical Temperament
help.body: • Slider for Steps: Use the slider to adjust the number of steps (N) in the octave. As you move the slider, you will see how changing the number of steps affects the approximation of the perfect fifth ratio (3:2)

interactive_data.sliderHeading: Test different values of N to see which gives integer-ish k:
interactive_data.excellentChoiceDescription: N = 12 gives k ≈ 7.02, very close to 7. This is why 12-tone equal temperament became the standard.
interactive_data.seventeenToneDescription: N = 17 gives k ≈ 9.94, very close to 10. Used in other tuning systems but harder to play on traditional instruments.
interactive_data.nineteenToneDescription: N = 19 gives k ≈ 11.11, very close to 11. More accurate for some intervals but makes instrument design more complicated.
interactive_data.veryAccurateDescription: N = 24 gives k ≈ 14.04, very close to 14. Gets even closer to the 3:2 ratio but harder to play on traditional instruments.

S7.S7_D1_F41_C2: See, we start by thinking about this: when we divide the octave into N equal steps, the frequency of the note at each step is 21/N times the frequency of the note at the previous step.
S7.S7_D2_F42_C1: Okay, so with each step, we're slowly climbing up the octave?
S7.S7_D3_F43_C2: That's right! Now, remember, we love the sound of the perfect fifth — that's a 3:2 ratio. So, the question becomes: after how many steps, say k steps, do we get as close as possible to that perfect fifth ratio?
S7.S7_D4_F44_C1: So we're looking for the value of k that gets us to the 3:2 mark?
S7.S7_D5_F45_C2: Yes! Mathematically, we want (21/N)k = 3/2. This means after k steps, we've climbed up to a frequency that's in the perfect fifth position.
S7.S7_D6_F46_C1: Got it. But how do we find k?
S7.S7_D7_F47_C2: Good question! We can rearrange the equation. First, we take the log base 2 of both sides. That gives us: k/N = log2(3/2).
S7.S7_D8_F48_C1: Okay, so now we just multiply both sides by N?
S7.S7_D9_F49_C2: Yup! So, k = N × log2(3/2) which eventually gives us k ≈ 0.58496 × N.
S7.S7_D10_F50_C1: Alright, so now we try different values of N to see when k becomes a whole number?
S7.S7_D11_F51_C2: Spot on! Now, try moving the slider and watch how k changes. Can you spot which N makes k almost a whole number?
S7.S7_D12_F52_C1: Hmm... I see that when N is 12, k is around 7.02 — that's pretty close to a whole number!
S7.S7_D13_F53_C2: Correct! That's one reason why 12 steps per octave became the standard — the perfect fifth lands close to a whole number of steps, making it easy to play. But try a few other values too
S7.S7_D14_F54_C1: Looks like N = 7, 17, and 24 also give k values that are pretty close to whole numbers.
S7.S7_D15_F55_C2: Good catch! Those are used in other tuning systems, like 7-tone and 24-tone scales. Some get even closer to the 3:2 ratio — but they're not as common, since they're harder to play on traditional instruments.
S7.S7_D14_F56_C1: What about N = 19? It gives k around 11.1 — that seems really close too.
S7.S7_D15_F57_C2: Yep! The 19-tone scale is a great example. It's more accurate for some intervals, but it makes instrument design and playing a bit more complicated. 12 is a great compromise — close enough to key intervals and practical for musicians.
S7.S7_D16_F56_C1: So, 12 steps really are a smart choice!
S7.S7_D17_F57_C2: Yes it is! It balances mathematical accuracy and playability. That's why most modern instruments, like pianos and guitars, use 12 semitones per octave.
S7.S7_D18_F58_C1: And because k is about 7 when N is 12, that means the 7th note in the scale lands close to the perfect fifth, right?
S7.S7_D19_F59_C2: Precisely! Starting from any note, if you count 7 steps up in a 12-tone scale, you land on a note that's very close to a 3:2 frequency ratio — that's the perfect fifth. And that's one reason the 12-step system sounds so natural to our ears.

S8.S8_D1_F58_C1: Hmm... I think I get it now. Since an octave is a 2:1 ratio, dividing it into 12 steps means after 12 steps the frequency will be doubled.
S8.S8_D2_FX_C2: Yes. But now the question is what constant factor must each step multiply by so that after 12 steps the frequency will be doubled.
S8.S8_D3_FX_C2: Let's say we start with base frequency f, we need to find a constant factor r so that if we repeatedly multiply f with r for 12 times, we arrive at 2f.
S8.S8_D4_FX_C1: So f multiply by r raised to the power of 12 equals to 2ff × r12 = 2f which means r raised to the power of 12 equals to 2r12 = 2. Therefore r equals to 2 raised to the power of 1 over 12r = 21/12.
S8.S8_D5_F59_C2: That's right! Each semitone moves us a little higher, multiplying the frequency by about 1.0595 — that's 21/12 or twelfth root of 2, since fractional exponents and roots mean the same thing.
S8.S8_D6_F60_C1: But wait… this makes me wonder. We're using 2 because an octave is a 2:1 ratio, right? What if we used a different base? Like, what if we thought of the octave as something like 1.5 or 3 instead of 2?
S8.S8_D7_F61_C2: Ah, that’s a brilliant question! If we change the base value, we change how much the frequency changes with each step increase. It would give us a completely different scale.
S8.S8_D8_F62_C1: Really? So the steps would be smaller or larger depending on the base?

S9_D0_F64_C9.title: Beyond the Octave: Reimagining Musical Scales

about.heading: Understanding Musical Scale Mathematics
about.body:
What is a Musical Scale?

A musical scale is a sequence of musical notes arranged by frequency. In Western music, we use the equal-tempered scale, which divides an octave into 12 equally-spaced steps called semitones.

Exploring Different Base Values:

The first formula explores how different base values affect a single note's frequency:

f(x) = 440 × (x)1 / 12

Where:

  • f(x) = frequency of one step above the starting note in Hz
  • 440 = frequency of the base note in Hz
  • x = base value (experimental octave ratio)
  • 1 / 12 = the fractional exponent representing one step out of 12

Why do bases other than 2 sound wrong?

  • Base 1.5: Each step multiplies by 1.51/12 ≈ 1.035 (too small - melody sounds "squeezed")
  • Base 2.5: Each step multiplies by 2.51/12 ≈ 1.080 (too large - melody sounds "stretched")
  • Base 4: Each step multiplies by 41/12 ≈ 1.122 (much too large - melody sounds "pulled apart")
  • Only base 2 gives the perfect step size: 21/12 ≈ 1.059

Building the Complete 12-Note Scale:

With the base fixed at 2, we can calculate the frequency of any note in the full scale:

f(n) = 440 × (2)n / 12

Where:

  • f(n) = frequency of the nth note in Hz
  • n = step number (0 through 12)
  • 12 in the denominator divides the octave into 12 equal steps

help.heading: How to use this Tool?
help.body:
Exploring Different Base Values:

  • Start by clicking "Mary Lamb" with base 2 selected to hear how the standard scale sounds.
  • Listen carefully to how the melody flows - this is your reference point.
  • Experimenting with base values:
    • Try each base value button (1.5, 2.5, 3, 4) and replay the melody.
    • Pay attention to how the melody sounds different with each base.
    • Notice whether the tune sounds "squeezed together" or "stretched out".
  • Understanding the Math:
    • Look at the frequency formula and the example calculation shown
    • Each base value creates a different step size between notes
    • The graph shows how frequency changes as you adjust the base value

Building the Complete Scale:

  • Notice that the base is now fixed at 2, but you can explore different step numbers (n)
  • Use the frequency formula f(n) = 440 × (2)n / 12 to calculate frequencies
  • The graph shows all 12 steps of the chromatic scale
  • Working with the Formula:
    • Start with step 0 (n = 0)
    • Substitute different values of n into the formula
    • Check your calculations against the table provided
  • Key Mathematical Concepts:
    • Each step multiplies the previous frequency by the same ratio
    • After 12 steps, the frequency should double (creating an octave)
    • The exponent n / 12 represents what fraction of an octave you've traveled

S9.S9_D1_FX_C2: Before changing to any other base, let's first hear our classic "Mary Had a Little Lamb" — it's a great melody for noticing how the notes naturally step across the scale — using the standard base of 2.
S9.S9_D2_FX_C1: Ah, now that feels familiar! The tune sounds clean and just right.
S9.S9_D3_FX_C2: Exactly! That's the magic of base 2 — it gives us the natural flow our ears expect.
S9.S9_D4_FX_C2: With base 2, each step multiplies the frequency by the same factor: the twelfth root of 2 or 2 raised to the power of 1 over 1221/12 which is about 1.059. That's what gives us 12 evenly spaced notes that land perfectly one octave above the starting pitch.
S9.S9_D5_FX_C2: Now, let's change the base to 1.5 and play "Mary Had a Little Lamb" again to hear how it sounds!
S9.S9_D6_FX_C1: Whoa! That sounds... way off! Like Mary's lamb got completely lost!
S9.S9_D7_FX_C2: Right? Since the base is smaller, the steps between notes shrink — so the melody gets all squeezed and loses its shape.
S9.S9_D8_FX_C2: With base 1.5, each step only multiplies by the twelfth root of 1.5 or 1 point 5 raised to the power of 1 over 121.51/12 — which is about 1.035. So each note steps up less, and everything sounds squeezed together.
S9.S9_D10_FX_C2: Go ahead and explore some of the other base values too — like 2.5, 3, or even 4. It's fun to hear how each one reshapes the melody.
S9.S9_D11_FX_C1: Huh... none of them really feel right. Some sound stretched out, some squished — just not how a song should sound.
S9.S9_D12_FX_C2: That's because each base changes how quickly the frequency grows between notes.
S9.S9_D13_FX_C2: For example, base 2.5 gives us steps of the twelfth root of 2.5 or 2 point 5 raised to the power of 1 over 122.51/12 — which is about 1.08 — a bit too much. Base 4 jumps all the way to around twelfth root of 4 or 4 raised to the power of 1 over 1241/12 — which is about 1.12 per step! That’s why everything sounds too spread out — like the melody’s been pulled apart.
S9.S9_D14_FX_C2: Mathematically, they all follow the same pattern — multiplying by the 12th root of the base — but only base 2 gives us that perfectly balanced step size that lands on a clean, doubled frequency after 12 steps.
S9.S9_D15_FX_C2: That's why musicians use base 2: it sounds smooth, natural, and complete — just the way our ears like it.
S9.S9_D16_FX_C2: Now that we understand why base 2 is the best choice, let's explore how it shapes the full scale. With base 2 fixed, we can move through all twelve notes, each one a step in the equal-tempered scale.
S9.S9_D17_FX_C1: So each step increases the frequency by the same amount?
S9.S9_D18_FX_C2: Not exactly the same amount, but by the same ratio. Each note's frequency is calculated using this formula: f(n) = 440 × (2)n/12, where n is the number of steps from the starting note, which is 440 Hz.
S9.S9_D19_FX_C1: So if I want the frequency of the 3rd step, I just plug in n = 3 in the formula?
S9.S9_D20_FX_C2: Yes. What will be the frequency (in Hz) of the 3rd step?
S9.S9_D21_FX_C1: So after 12 steps, the frequency doubles and we reach the same note one octave higher.
S9.S9_D22_FX_C2: Correct! That's the beauty of the equal-tempered scale—each step builds consistently on the one before it.

S10.S10_D1_F72_C2: Alright, now that we've finalized the base value and explored how to calculate frequency of any note, let's build a synth for your school fair.
S10.S10_D2_F73_C2: Each note becomes 21/12 times the previous one.
S10.S10_D3_F74_C1: So if I have to build my synth, I'd just need to make sure each note is 21/12 apart in frequency?
S10.S10_D4_F75_C2: Exactly! That's the foundation of your synth. Start from your base note, and multiply by 21/12 for each step you move up.

about.heading: Understanding the Synthesizer
about.body: • This simple synthesizer built with equal temperament scale lets you hear how each semitone is equidistant from each other

help.heading: How to Use the Synthesizer
help.body: • Press the buttons to play scales or well-known melodies like "Mary Had a Little Lamb" or "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star." Click "Stop" to halt the sound

S11.S11_D1_F78_C1: Alright, check this out — this is what I came up with!
S11.S11_D2_FX_C1: I've set it up so my base note starts at, say, 440 Hz, and every next note multiplies by 21/12. Now I've got a full keyboard! It's like I've built a mini version of the piano.
S11.S11_D3_FX_C1: Click on "Play Scale" to hear all 12 notes together.
S11.S11_D4_F81_C2: Impressive! You've built your very own synth, using everything you've learned about sound, math, and music. You're ready to start making some serious music now!
S11.S11_D5_FX_C1: Click on "Twinkle" to play our classic "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star" nursery rhyme.

S12.S12_D1_F82_C2: Great job, Emery! You've used math to create your very own synth and learned how music is built on ratios and frequencies.
S12.S12_D2_F83_C1: It's amazing! I never realized how much math is behind the music we hear every day, but now I get it!
S12.S12_D3_F84_C2: Exactly! Now you can experiment with scales, melodies, and different ratios to create your own sounds.
S12.S12_D4_F85_C1: I'm excited to keep exploring. I've got the tools to make music just the way I want!

quest_completion.subheading: You Explored How to Create a Synth Using Math
quest_completion.content:
You've successfully completed the Synth Builder STEAMQuest!

  • You learned how musical scales and frequencies are built using mathematical ratios
  • You explored how dividing the octave into 12 steps gives us the familiar 2:1 ratio for natural harmony
  • You experimented with different bases using a radical function to see how they affect the sound of melodies and scales
  • You learned to build your own synth, applying equal temperament to create a working keyboard with natural intervals
Your journey of exploring sound and math has just begun. Explore more, create new tunes, and keep experimenting with sound!

equal_temperament.definition: Equal Temperament is a tuning system where the octave is divided into equal steps, making it possible to play in any key without retuning. The most common version divides the octave into 12 equal semitones.

frequency.definition: Frequency is the number of vibrations per second, measured in Hertz (Hz), which determines the pitch of a sound.

harmonies.definition: Harmonies are combinations of notes played together that create pleasing sounds, often built using mathematical ratios between frequencies.

melodies.definition: Melodies are sequences of notes played one after another to create musical phrases and recognizable tunes.

note.definition: A Note is a musical sound with a specific pitch, represented by a letter name (A, B, C, etc.) and corresponding to a particular frequency.

octave.definition: An Octave is the interval between two notes where the higher note has twice the frequency of the lower note.

pitch.definition: Pitch is how high or low a sound is perceived, determined by the frequency of the sound wave.

semitone.definition: A Semitone is the smallest musical interval in equal temperament, represented as one step on a piano keyboard.

synth.definition: A Synth is an electronic instrument that generates sound through mathematical functions and waveforms.
